'''Herman Chernoff''' (born July 1, 1923, [[New York]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[applied mathematics|applied]] [[mathematician]], [[statistician]] and [[physicist]] formerly a professor at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] and currently working at [[Harvard University]].<ref>

</ref>

In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2012-11-10.</ref>

==Early life and education==
Herman Chernoff's parents were Pauline and Max Chernoff, Jewish immigrants from Russia. He studied in Townsend Harris High School.<ref>[http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/history/Biographies/Chernoff.html Chernoff biography]</ref>

* Ph.D., Applied Mathematics, 1948. [[Brown University]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.stat.harvard.edu/People/Faculty/Herman_Chernoff/Herman_Chernoff_Education_and_Previous_Positions.html | title = Education and Previous Positions | accessdate = October 7, 2008 | author = Herman Chernoff | year = 2005 }}</ref>
* M.S., Applied Mathematics, 1945. [[Brown University]].
* B.S., Mathematics, 1943. [[City College of New York]].
